Arts Reviews

Review: Down the Rabbit Hole

By James Bithell

Robbie Nestor guides us through Drama Barn's fantastical and surreal Down the Rabbit Hole

The Path of Playhouse Creatures

By James Bithell

Amy Williams lets us in on what to expect from the exciting and upcoming performance of Playhouse Creatures

Review: Matisse: From Tate Modern and MoMA

By James Bithell

Kirsty Henley-Washford reviews the first in a series of screenings at York Picturehouse. Looking back on the life of Henri Matisse, the Tate Modern exhibits its collection of his 'cut-out' pieces and their significance.

Review: Cell

By James Bithell

A curiously heart-warming performance, Lily Papworth reviews Cell at York Theatre Royal's Takeover Festival 2014

Review: Helver's Night

By James Bithell

Lily Papworth reviews the final performance of Helver's Night, a gripping yet movingly tragic play, at York Theatre Royal.

Review: The School For Wives

By James Bithell

Lily Papworth reviews Drama Barn's quirky comedy on married life, The School for Wives

Review: The Office Trip

By James Bithell

Declan Dillane reviews Drama Soc's unconventional The Office Trip

Review: What Becomes?

By James Bithell

A gripping and thought-provoking performance, Matthew Ingram reviews Drama Barn's 'What Becomes?'

Review: The Kite Runner

By James Bithell

Louisa Britton reviews the fantastic yet moving performance of 'The Kite Runner' at York Theatre Royal.

Review: Say Owt Poetry Slam

By James Bithell

Say Owt gives a promising voice to York's poetry slammers. Kate Marshall reviews.

Review: House of Hell

By James Bithell

DramaSoc's Open Drama Night offers up an exciting Halloween-inspired comedy that certainly amused Niall Whitehead.

Review: Welcome to Night Vale - The Librarian

Welcome to Night Vale's wickedly brilliant podcast will get you in the mood for Halloween. Niall Whitehead reviews.

Review: Lord of the Flies

DramaSoc manages to bring a powerfully nuanced interpretation to a literary canon

Review: Antigone

Despite attempts at a daring modernised version of Sophocles' canonical tragedy, Pilot Theatre's adaptation is underwhelming. Louisa Britton reviews.

Review: Immaculate

Jaz Hayward is pleasantly surprised by the Drama Barn's take on the immaculate conception.

Review: Journey's End

Jacob Miller reviews DramaSoc at its very best

Review: The Man Jesus

Emma Ralph is blown away by Simon Callow in this one man show

Review: Betrayal

A solid attempt at a difficult play, although nothing about it was strikingly unique. Amy Blumsom reviews.

Review: Nineteen Eighty-Four

Headlong Theatre's latest adaptation of Nineteen Eighty-Four brings a powerfully compelling new dimension to Orwell's classic. Alex Slingsby reviews.

Edinburgh Fringe Review: Winter of our Disotheque

Alexandra Hackitt-Anwyl reviews Drama Soc's Edinburgh offering

Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014 Review: The Shambles' Improvised Comedy

Despite comedic inertia, the York-based acting troupe's brave attempt at improv manages to impress Lily Luty

Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014 Review: Saucy Jack and the Space Vixens - Just the Tonic

Edinburgh's camp musical offering manages a perfect marriage of sexy, hilarious, and more than a little lewd. Lily Luty Reviews.

Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014 Review: Last Christmas

Despite its seasonally inappropriate subject matter, Last Christmas manages to impress Alex Hackitt-anwyl.

Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014 Review: Present and Correct: Now Recruiting

York Comedy Society's Edinburgh Fringe offering holds its own amidst the festival with its charming idiosyncratic humour. Alex Hackitt-anwyl reviews.

Review: HandleBards - Macbeth

Amy Wong is impressed with the HandleBards' second offering of the week

Review: HandleBards- The Comedy of Errors

Amy Wong reviews this delightfully madcap reinvention of Shakespeare's classic comedy

Review: Cendrillon

Following the success of Don Giovani, Opera Soc take on Massenet's masterpiece. Jaz Hayward reviews.

Review: Tonight at 8

By James Bithell

Jess Burgess reviews the Drama Barn's latest offering

Review: You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown

By James Bithell

"If six stars were possible, I'd still feel I was underselling it" Andrew Brannigan reviews.

Review: Evita

This production of Evita has made the West End staple its own. Jess Burgess reviews
